verses.text: The word that came to Jeremiah from the LORD, saying:
verses.comment: Jeremiah consistently emphasizes that his message is received directly from God, establishing his prophetic authority. For Protestants and other Christians, this is a reminder of God’s continued revelation through chosen messengers.

verses.text: "Hear the words of this covenant, and speak to the people of Judah and to the residents of Jerusalem.
verses.comment: The focus on covenant highlights the deep relational commitment God seeks from His people, foreshadowing the New Covenant in Christ. God calls His people to listen and respond to His revealed will.

verses.text: "You shall say to them, 'This is what the LORD, the God of Israel, says: Cursed is the person who does not obey the words of this covenant
verses.comment: The pronouncement of a curse for disobedience shows the seriousness of entering into covenant with God, much like sacramental commitments in the Christian tradition.

verses.text: which I commanded your ancestors when I brought them out of the land of Egypt, out of the iron furnace, saying, 'Obey My voice, and do everything I command you; then you shall be My people, and I will be your God.'
verses.comment: This verse connects Israel’s covenant to their deliverance from Egypt, a prefiguration of salvation, and the call to obedience as the means of remaining in God’s favor. The language of being “My people” is echoed in the New Testament church as the fulfillment of God’s promise.

verses.text: 'Then I will fulfill the oath I swore to your ancestors, to give them a land flowing with milk and honey, as it is today.'" And I answered, "Amen, LORD."
verses.comment: God’s faithful fulfillment of promise shows His reliability. Jeremiah’s response 'Amen' demonstrates liturgical affirmation, a tradition continued in Christian worship.

verses.text: Then the LORD said to me, "Proclaim all these words in the towns of Judah and in the streets of Jerusalem: 'Hear the words of this covenant and do them!'
verses.comment: Public proclamation and hearing underscore God’s desire that His commands be known and obeyed by the whole community, prefiguring the church’s mission to preach and teach.

verses.text: For I earnestly warned your ancestors from the day I brought them out of Egypt, until this day, warning persistently, saying, 'Obey My voice!'
verses.comment: God’s persistence in calling Israel to obedience demonstrates His patient love. This is a reminder that God continues to draw His people back through His prophets and through the Church’s teaching.

verses.text: But they did not listen or pay attention; each one followed the stubbornness of his evil heart. So I brought upon them all the words of this covenant, which I commanded them to do, but they did not fulfill them."
verses.comment: Human stubbornness leads to judgment. The failure to keep covenant points to the need for divine grace to overcome the hardness of heart—a theme fully realized in Christ’s redemption.

verses.text: Again the LORD said to me, "A conspiracy has been found among the people of Judah and the residents of Jerusalem.
verses.comment: The idea of conspiracy shows collective rebellion, symbolizing the spiritual infidelity which eventually requires God’s intervention and restoration.

verses.text: They have returned to the sins of their ancestors, who refused to listen to My words; they have followed other gods to serve them. The house of Israel and the house of Judah have broken My covenant which I made with their ancestors."
verses.comment: Idolatry and covenant breaking are linked. The unity between Israel and Judah’s failure hints at humanity’s need for united spiritual guidance, leading toward the fullness of restored worship in the future Messianic Kingdom.

verses.text: Therefore this is what the LORD says: 'I am about to bring disaster on them that they cannot escape; though they cry out to Me, I will not listen to them.'
verses.comment: God’s refusal to hear their cries underlines the seriousness of persistent sin. This serves as a warning and shows the importance of true repentance and intercessory prayer.

verses.text: Then the towns of Judah and the residents of Jerusalem will go and cry out to the gods to whom they offer incense, but they will not save them at all in their time of trouble.
verses.comment: The futility of trusting in false gods becomes apparent. This reinforces the exclusivity of worshipping the one true God.

verses.text: For your gods have become as numerous as your towns, Judah; and you have set up altars to that shameful thing, altars to burn incense to Baal, as many as the streets of Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Multiplication of idols reflects spiritual confusion. The spiritual danger of sacrificing to false gods is a recurring warning throughout Scripture.

verses.text: "So you must not pray for these people or lift up a cry or prayer for them, for I will not hear them in the time they call to Me because of their disaster."
verses.comment: Jeremiah is commanded not to intercede, showing a limit to prophetic intercessory prayer when the people remain unrepentant. This echoes the gravity of sin which can even restrict intercession.

verses.text: "What right does My beloved have in My house, when she has done so many evil things? Can sacrifices and holy flesh avert your disaster while you do evil and rejoice?"
verses.comment: Sacrifices are insufficient without repentance and morality. This prefigures the necessity of sincere faith and living out God’s commands, not mere ritual.

verses.text: The LORD called you an olive tree, beautiful with good fruit. But with the noise of great tumult He has set it on fire, and its branches are broken.
verses.comment: Israel as the olive tree is a metaphor picked up in Romans 11 for the Church. The breaking off of branches shows the consequences of unfaithfulness, while later restoration points to God’s mercy and the inclusion of Gentiles.

verses.text: The LORD of Hosts, who planted you, has pronounced disaster on you because of the evil of the house of Israel and the house of Judah, which they have done, provoking Me to anger by burning incense to Baal.
verses.comment: God as the planter shows His sovereignty, and His right to judge. The reference to burning incense to Baal calls to mind the conflict between true worship and idolatry.

verses.text: The LORD made it known to me, and I knew; then You showed me their deeds.
verses.comment: Jeremiah’s prophetic intimacy with God and revelation shows the close relationship a true servant of God can have. Notice the spiritual discernment given to those who are faithful.

verses.text: But I was like a gentle lamb led to the slaughter; I did not know they had plotted against me, saying, 'Let us destroy the tree with its fruit, let us cut him off from the land of the living, that his name may be remembered no more.'
verses.comment: This verse foreshadows the suffering servant motif fulfilled in Christ. The plot to kill Jeremiah echoes the conspiracy against Jesus, who was led like a lamb to the slaughter (Isa. 53:7-8).

verses.text: But, O LORD of Hosts, You who judge righteously, who test the heart and mind, let me see Your vengeance on them, for to You I have revealed my case.
verses.comment: God’s righteous judgment and the testing of hearts is a key theme. Jeremiah entrusts his cause to God, much like Christ entrusted His soul to the Father on the cross.

verses.text: Therefore this is what the LORD says concerning the men of Anathoth, who seek your life, saying, 'Do not prophesy in the name of the LORD, or you will die by our hand.'
verses.comment: Opposition to true prophecy, even within Jeremiah’s hometown, mirrors later resistance to God’s messengers, including Jesus. Prophetic suffering is a theme which continues to be relevant.

verses.text: Therefore this is what the LORD of Hosts says: 'Behold, I will punish them. The young men will die by the sword; their sons and daughters will die by famine.'
verses.comment: God’s judgment will not spare even the young, showing the importance of collective and generational faithfulness to God.

verses.text: "Not even a remnant will remain for them, for I will bring disaster on the men of Anathoth in the year of their punishment."
verses.comment: The lack of remnant for the men of Anathoth stands in contrast with God’s promise elsewhere to preserve a remnant of His faithful. This underscores the seriousness of rejecting God’s prophets and highlights that true restoration comes only through fidelity and perseverance to the end.
